awd_titl_txt: Transforming STEM Education at a Research 1 University through Multi-Level Action Teams
awd_abstract_narration:
A well-prepared workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is a national priority that underpins progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy.  To educate this future STEM workforce, colleges and universities need to accelerate the adoption of effective teaching and learning practices at scale.  This project at the University of Georgia aims to implement the University's new core commitments to designing high-quality, more effective educational experiences for STEM students by: developing clear and measurable learning outcomes, basing educational decisions on evidence, collaborating on undergraduate education, fostering continuous teaching improvement, and promoting inclusion and diversity.  To achieve these goals, this project will develop teams to design and implement the necessary changes at the course, department, and institutional levels.  If successful, this project could provide an example of how to make sustainable institutional change that increases the quality undergraduate education, and broadens the success of students in STEM fields.

Grounded in social cognition and cultural change theory, this project will develop and coordinate action teams at the three organizational levels: the course level, the department level, and the institutional level.  At the course level, instructional action teams, involving 84 faculty in biology, chemistry, physics, engineering, mathematics, and statistics, will revise courses to achieve foundational learning outcomes. At the department level, a leadership action team, involving twelve department heads, will meet regularly to reconsider department policies and practices, including the way that departments evaluate and recognize teaching for promotion and tenure. At the institution level, strategic action teams comprised of faculty, department heads, and deans will work to revise institutional practices, such as the teaching evaluation system, which currently interferes with the quality of education at the University. Longitudinal data will be collected from all action team participants to investigate the extent to which the multi-level action teams produce shifts in assumptions, values, and beliefs, and result in new policies and practices. Data sources will include interviews, surveys, teaching observations, course-based assessments, audio-recordings of action team meetings, and artifacts revealing departmental and university policies. All data will be analyzed according to standard qualitative and quantitative protocols.  Results will be disseminated through publications, conferences, press releases, and other avenues, with attention to situating the project results in context of related findings from other research-intensive institutions. This strategy can enhance the potential that similar institutions will be able to adopt or adapt successful institutional change models to accelerate improvement of their learning environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Department and Leadership Teams for Action (DeLTA) project has achieved multiple important outcomes for teaching evaluation at research-intensive universities in the United States by showing institutions how to curb overreliance on flawed student end-of-course surveys and increase the use of additional forms of evidence of teaching effectiveness. 

 

First, DeLTA designed and tested a model for department-level change related to teaching evaluation practices. The DeLTA model involves department chairs and faculty leaders from their departments working in parallel and as a team to prioritize, design, and implement new teaching evaluation practices. Department chairs meet as a group to learn about new practices and discuss how to lead their units towards change. Faculty leaders meet separately as a group to decide the best place to initiate changes to teaching evaluation practices, design those changes, and pilot test changes in their units. Together department chairs and faculty leaders bring these ideas to their department, organize the department to implement the new practices, gather feedback, and revise as needed. 

 

Second, DeLTA catalyzed improvements in teaching evaluation practices among 31 departments at the University of Georgia, including 25 STEM departments and six departments beyond STEM. DeLTA also spearheaded university policy changes that improved the types and expectations of evidence that faculty and departments can provide to document teaching effectiveness. 

 

Third, research on the DeLTA model demonstrated that departments that engage in the DeLTA model can shift their teaching evaluation practices toward a more evidence-based approach. Additionally, higher degrees of change are achieved in departments that are ready for change, as defined by research from organizational psychology. Readiness for change occurs when department members believe that the change is needed and that their department has the ability to achieve the change. Research from DeLTA also created a new readiness for change survey that can help departments and change agents assess departmental readiness to undergo change. Further, research from DeLTA used a leadership model from business management to describe the leadership strategies that effective department chairs used to lead change, such as communicating about the benefits and feasibility of the change. 

 

Fourth, the knowledge and tools generated by DeLTA have been disseminated widely through academic publications, university websites, disciplinary conferences, and presentations and workshops at institutions for higher education and associated organizations, as well as through one-on-one consultation with other institutions. Thus, the project has led to changes not only at the University of Georgia but also at other colleges and universities across the country. The broad dissemination of the work indicates that numerous higher education institutions are building upon the work of DeLTA to create their own improvements in teaching evaluation. 

 

Finally, DeLTA has facilitated the growth of human resources on multiple fronts. A total of 72 faculty and administrators have learned about improved teaching evaluation. These faculty span 31 departments that are home to an additional 900+ faculty indirectly affected by changes to teaching evaluation. This comprises almost half of the faculty on campus who have instructional responsibilities and thus have the potential to impact the learning and educational experiences of thousands of current and future students. In addition, DeLTA has built human resources for STEM education by employing, mentoring, and training 13 undergraduate and graduate research assistants and three postdoctoral scholars.
